entry.title: Find a place for everything
entry.content:
I know it sounds like a basic principle, but how many of us follow it? If you find that your workspaces or home are constantly getting filled with clutter every few days, it’s possible you don’t have a place for everything!

I spent this whole weekend reorganizing my home office to not only ensure that every object had a place, but also items that are used less often are put in harder to reach spots and items that I use or need more frequently in very easy to reach places. That way, when I’m done with something that I use often, it immediately gets put back in its spot.

I’ve also found that the shoebox containers from The Container Store are very nice to have and I highly recommend buying their 20 count box. Pair those with a label maker and you are set off to a great start towards being more organized.

entry.title: Switching to Octopress
entry.content:
Yes, at least for now, I’ve decided that I was tired of dealing with Wordpress. In an effort to lower my costs and headache for owning and operating a personal blog, Octopress paired with Jekyll seemed like an awesome alternative for someone who enjoys writing in plain text as much as myself.

I was inspired by a couple of folks to make the switch. All in all, it was actually not too bad once I got the latest version of Ruby and RVM setup on my Mac.

EDIT

It’s also worthy to note that I used exitwp to migrate my wordpress content into markdown. I realize there are a few bugs that I need to iron out and will do that soon.

Furthermore, check out http://pages.github.com/ if you are ever interested in free static stite hosting on github. Seems pretty good for a personal blog setup.

entry.title: Lee, the Patriot
entry.content:
Today, as I looked upon the new resting place of my dear great Uncle Lee, I had a revelation that left me distraught. Lee was a part of the World War II generation—specifically, he fought and was wounded in the Battle of Bulge. That global conflict, the worst our world has seen, defines to me what the cost of freedom was for the United States we have today. As a citizen of this country, I was embarrassed and disappointed with myself when I realized how much my generation and I take this costly freedom for granted. I don’t think we can truly appreciate it since we have not suffered what the world suffered then.

Lee’s generation knows the pain and suffering of what it means to be free—they understand patriotism on a different level from what my generation could ever imagine. I’m so thankful for the amazing patriot he was and his bold testament to the world as such a great, funny, and loving man to his family, first and foremost to his wife. Naturally, my first regret was that I did not know him better and did not visit with him more. His wartime generation could teach my generation a lot if we were so humble to listen.

As I sit here and think about what patriotism means to me and consider what it must have meant to Lee, I can’t help but shed tears in the memory of what dies along with him—an understanding of what it means to be an American, a citizen of this great country.

Funerals bring one to reflect on one’s own life. Lee’s passing encouraged me to have a more serious and solemn appreciation for all of the brave men and women of our nation who serve and have served us so dutifully.

My deepest sympathy and compassion go out to my family in this sorrowful time. May we not dwell on what we’ve lost, but instead look forward to what he taught us and how he inspired us.

Rest in peace, dear Lee.

entry.title: It's about the customer service
entry.content:
Some companies get it, some don’t; quality customer service does matter and does leave a lasting impression. From the time an individual first walks into a store, logs in online, or approaches the host/hostess at a restaurant, the subconscious evaluation of customer service begins. Akin to first impressions when meeting someone for the first time, immediately you begin making judgements about how you are treated, e.g., whether you were greeted in a courteous manner, asked if you need help, etc. From this point forward, it’s the company’s duty to draw you in, and give you reason to hand over your hard earned money in exchange for their product or service. You likely preconceived doing this anyway otherwise you would not have approached them in the first place. However, there are many alternatives and you could change your mind and go somewhere else if you’ve not found what you’re looking for or you’ve not received the service you expect.

I am constantly on the lookout for companies and organizations who treat their customers well. In many cases, I’m likely to pay more for a product or service to receive such quality treatment. Some of the companies who top my list are those whom offer great customer service that may not be known for it or may be less expected to are Zappos.com, Apple, Amazon.com, and Costco. They have no particular obligation as say Nordstrom does in offering the best service in their industry. Yet, they understand the value. I’ve had a couple of interactions with each of these recently and would like to lay them out beginning with Apple.

Apple

One evening when making spiced apple cider last autumn, I received a phone call. I went to pick up my iPhone and unlocked it—as I did, the phone some how slipped out of my hand and plopped, fully submerged into the large bowl of hot apple cider (slightly ironic). I don’t think I’ve ever reacted to something so quickly! I reached into the bowl to save the life of my iPhone, wiped it down and took a can of compressed air to try and get as much liquid out as possible. All seemed fine and it appeared to have been saved—until the next day. Unfortunately whatever damage had been done had set into the electronics of the phone and I was not able to hear the person on the other line very well when listening to the earpiece. Naturally, I was quite bummed.

After much consideration, I decided I was going to take it to the Genius Bar at my local Apple Store to see how much it was going to cost to repair. For all my mobile Apple products, I always buy AppleCare as I’ve found it’s usually pretty good insurance. Unfortunately, one of the things AppleCare does not cover is liquid damage. Nonetheless, I committed to myself I was going to tell the truth and not try to be like some of those people that I’ve seen go in and claim that the phone was not dropped in water even though the genius can clearly see that the liquid sensors in the iPhone have been activated.

When I arrived at the Apple store, I told the genius exactly what had happened. She was very understanding and asked to look at the iPhone to see if the liquid sensors had been damaged. After about five minutes, she came back and said the liquid sensors were not activated and questioned tongue-in-cheek, “so, you’re having trouble with your speaker, huh? Well, geez, that’s unfortunate, we need to get a replacement iPhone for you to see if that resolves the issue.” I was thrilled as she had just finished telling me it was going to be something in the range of $250 to get it replaced. This is customer service.

Amazon.com

I’ve long been a customer of Amazon.com and am a strong advocate of their retail philosophies. There are many things that I love about their shopping experience, from their breadth of product offerings, to their Prime shipping service. However, I would like to focus on their Subscribe & Save service. If you have not had the pleasure of ordering a product with Subscribe & Save, I highly recommend you find something of interest and give it a try, it really is worth it.

Offered on a limited set of products that you would likely purchase routinely, Subscribe & Save allows you to opt-in to receive a designated item or usually a multi-pack of items every so often. For example, one of the things I have subscribed to is three packages of cat litter for our automatic litterbox. I receive these three cartons of litter every three months and it is automatically shipped. The advantages are for the customer is 1) you can cancel any time so you are not obligated to a pre-determined number of shipments, 2) you get free shipping on the item, 3) you get a 15% discount off the purchase price and 4) you get to choose the delivery frequency. Pretty sweet deal if you ask me. One might think that this is one of those marketing ploys where they make the offer look attractive by getting you to sign up and making it difficult to unsubscribe or they don’t warn you when a shipment is about to go out to give you enough time to cancel. I’m happy to report it is not at all like this. In fact, Amazon sends you an email a few days before the shipment leaves the warehouse to give you time to cancel. This is customer service.

Costco

I’ve been a member of Costco for quite some time as they consistently offer quality products. I find the small membership fee to be well worth the value and service I get from this retailer. If you are familiar with Costco, you are probably also familiar with their lifetime unconditional guarantee they offer on most of their products (“most?”, yes, unfortunately customers began abusing the system on things like computers, televisions, and cell phones, so they had to limit some items to a three month guarantee). This incredible guarantee states that if you are ever dissatisfied with any product or purchase you make, you can return the item(s) for a full refund, no questions asked.

I have known about this little perk for some time now, but never had the oppotunity to utilize it—until recently. A year and a half ago, I purchased an HP inkjet printer from Costco. I’ve been a long time fan of HP, until the past couple of printers and ink supplies I’ve purchased. This printer worked pretty well for the first six months. However, the next six months it got really bad with paper jams so much so that only about 10% of our print jobs were successful. I was really bummed, until I realized that this was an opportunity to take advantage of the Costco guarantee. I called them up and asked if I could bring the printer in for a refund, they responded that as long as I had the receipt as well as the cables and such that came with it, it was not an issue. I did just that. The process was very simple and was a very normal return process—I didn’t even have the original box. This is customer service.

Zappos.com

Finally, I would like to describe my most recent act of quality customer service which was with Zappos.com. As someone who rarely has time to visit a brick and mortar store to shop, especially for shoes, Zappos.com has become an excellent convenience. While their prices seem to be standard and aren’t much cheaper if I bought them in person some where, their service is incredible and their model is second-to-none. For starters, they offer free shipping to you and free shipping back to them if you decide to return your purchase. For VIP members (which is no extra cost to become one), that shipping is automatically upgraded to overnight. They take the baton even further by offering a very user-friendly site that is clear, fast, and offers an excellent alternative to in person shoe shopping—by providing pictures and video of all angles of the shoe. Finally, to top it off, I had a specific scenario that really made this company stand out.

While I’ve only ever purchased shoes from them, I decided to take a look at the options they had for other clothes. I found a safe bet in a pair of jeans that appeared to fit the bill and were at a good price point. I made the purchase and went about my business. The next day I had the following email in my inbox:

Hello Kyle,

We were unable to process your order for the Nautica Relaxed Fit Jean on order number Order #[removed]. Please accept our sincerest apologies. Regrettably, the merchandise did not pass our quality inspection and we do not have a replacement available in stock in the size and color you requested.

Since the item is unavailable, we have canceled your order and voided the authorization on your credit card. Please be advised that it could take your bank 2-10 business days to release the authorization placed on your account for this order.

We have conducted a search of other internet retailers and were unable to find the item available elsewhere. In case you’d like to wait and see if we get this item back in stock, we have added you to our “notify me” list. Being placed on the “notify me” list does not require any obligation on your part. Please review the link below for more information about our Notification List and how it works:

http://www.zappos.com/general-questions#out-of-stock

This order is not indicative of the high quality of service and products we strive to provide our customers. As a gesture of goodwill, we have issued a $10.00 coupon which you may use toward your next purchase at Zappos.com. Below is the coupon code you will need to receive your discount….

I was astounded. How could an online retailer give me such joy after informing they were not able to complete my order. Let’s point out a few items of interest here.

First, I received this email the day after I made the purchase. In cases where I have had back orders in the past with other retailers, the company has notified me no less than a week later and they apologize then simply say it will be in when it will be in.

The next point of good service is the very first point in the letter; they inspected the item and it did not pass their standards of quality. When ordering from an online retailer, this step is imperative yet so many miss it. Zappos.com understands that the quality of the product is important and that there is a chance that you will return it anyway if it is defective so they might as well take an extra moment for this inspection to save everyone the hassle later.

Following the inspection, they took the initiative to try and find the item from a nearby supplier. Since they were not able to and instead of leaving me in limbo indefinitely, they canceled my order to alive me of the burden of having to do so myself and going somewhere else.

Honestly, getting this far in the letter, I’m already a very happy customer (yes, even though I don’t have my product). To top things off even further, Zappos.com assured me that this was not a normal occurrence for them and as a nice gesture, they provided a $10 coupon to incentivize me to come back and to help alleviate any inconvenience this may have caused. I can’t say enough how important this one little letter is. This is customer service.

It’s not all good

The four previous examples are just a tiny fraction of stories out there about quality customer service. There is also the flip side of the coin, those companies who have poor customer service. I’m sure we could all name quite a few companies that we consistently have bad service from and eventually you learn just to avoid them where you can. I would only like to discuss a recent scenario I had with the single-cup coffee manufacturer, Tassimo.

Up until this past winter, when I switched to Nespresso for a far superior homemade espresso, I was a heavy consumer of Tassimo coffee and also a large proponent of their brand. It did what it claimed and did it decently—well enough for me to maintain a Tassimo Direct (a monthly subscription of coffee automatically shipped to your home) membership with them for three years. Last year, when I was evaluating alternatives to Tassimo, I put my Direct membership on a shipment hold for 6 months. Unfortunately, that 6 months was up recently. How did I know that? I was greeted by a lovely email yesterday saying I had a shipment of coffee on its way. I looked at the UPS tracking number and the shipment had actually gone out two days prior. Immediately irked that I did not receive any kind of email as a heads up that the shipment was going to occur, I picked up the phone to call their customer service.

Once connected to a human service representative, I explained the scenario. I’m not sure where this person was from but she was very monotone, dry, and pseudo-sympathetic to my issue. She “apologized” (as that’s probably what her script told her to say), and explained that I could put my shipment on hold for another 6 months. I replied with a stern “no” and said that I wanted to cancel the subscription entirely and that it was poor service of them to send out a shipment after a 6 month hold without so much as a courtesy email to the customer giving them a heads up and providing a means of canceling. She apologized again and replied with saying that the maximum hold for shipments is 6 months and offered to put my shipments on hold for another 6 months.

Obviously, she missed the point entirely because she wasn’t listening, or wasn’t comprehending the essence of the situation. I don’t blame her, English is likely not her native language and she’s just doing this job because it’s an income. I of course blame Tassimo. While they had lost a customer who was at one time loyal, they also lost someone who used to rave about their product and what a great alternative it was to other brands such as Keurig. If they continue to burn bridges, especially in terms of customer service, they will not be around much longer. As it is, it already seems they are not doing well with the rising popularity of Keurig and Nespresso systems.

Conclusion

I honestly don’t think I’m being unreasonable here to demand quality customer service from those whom I pay to provide me with a service or product. In my opinion, its a company’s responsibility to understand and sympathize with the needs of their customers. I’m not asking for monetary compensation every time they mess up, or provide a faulty product; all I ask from them is that they manage the situation in a courteous, efficient, and delightful manner (see the Zappos.com letter—even if you take out the $10 coupon, it is still is a great example of what I’m asking for).

Oftentimes, I’ve had people say to me how passionate I am about things I own, especially in regards to recent purchases. I am passionate and proud most of the time about the purchases I make. I strongly feel that I choose products that are high-quality or provide excellent utility or entertainment to me. When I find something that fits the bill, I will verbally share and sell that item to friends and family (on a recent occassion, I sold three Nespresso machines because people could see it was a quality product).

At the end of the day, I’ve not said anything that hasn’t been said before but it doesn’t hurt to bring it up again. In most cases, you do what you can to keep the customer happy. Do that, and you’ll win customers who will desire to work with you because they know you understand and appreciate them.

entry.title: Improve...don't prove
entry.content:
Whilst on the subway from work to Union Station in LA, I read an interesting and inspiring article in this month’s issue of Outdoor Photographer. It was an article titled Don’t Prove…Improve!, authored by nature photographer Dewitt Jones. Jones narrated the story of his first published photo which was in National Geographic and the experience he had in gaining a position there as a photographer. The aspect he was highlighting the most was the discussion he had with Bob Gilka, head of photography at National Geographic. Gilka provided a bit of sound advice that can certainly be applied to the programming field. Gilka told Jones that he was going to be working with the best photographers in the world and that Jones didn’t need to prove himself to Gilka or any of the other photographers he worked with. But the one thing he did ask from Jones was to improve himself—always aspire to be a better photographer.

This statement alone was enough to get me thinking about how relevant this was to me as a programmer, especially on a team of other programmers. I think it’s human nature for people to feel like they need to prove themselves to others and in some cases that’s true, but for day-to-day tasks and projects that you are collaborating with a team of people just like you, it’s pertinent to remember the advice Gilka so sincerely offered.

Gilka went on to say that his photographers are expected to share and learn from the other photographers. In other words, if you know of a technique, share with your team; if you’re in need of critique, be humbled and let others share with you. As programmers, there is no reason why we shouldn’t follow this same mantra; we should be lifting each other up and providing encouragement.

I work on a team where we get to work on some pretty great projects and so much of the time our pride can get in the way of great development, collaboration, and growth. This can cause issues from a few angles such as being protective of one’s code rather than looking at it as the team’s code and receiving feedback as a team to make it better. All in all it prevents the team from moving forward and progressing in terms of skills, technology, innovation, and team cohesion.

Jones describes his interaction with one of the photographers he met as well as others he got to know with the following quote, “Technical help, honest criticism and enthusiastic encouragement came from many, and my learning curve went up with the trajectory of a space shuttle launch.” How many of you can say the same thing about where you work? If you can, that’s fantastic! I would guess that it’s not the case for many.

He goes on to make another good point that over the years he has seen so many photographers waste time proving themselves to others that they missed the opportunities to spend those same hours “improving their technique and sharpening their eye”. How much better could we improve our development skills with this at the forefront of our minds?

What’s the solution? How can you bring this into your team? For starters, you can encourage your team to be more open. Speak to them about the benefits of having an openness such as is described above. They likely won’t come around instantly, but over time, the more you encourage this type of behavior, the more it will become natural and easy. It’s also good to encourage community code reviews where everyone and anyone can see and review code in a non- demeaning manner. Again, it’s for everyone’s own good—to help them grow—to help the team grow.

What are your thoughts? Can you relate to this?

entry.title: Make a shell script wait for you
entry.content:
Ever want a loop to wait for you? read will read a line for you to use, or in this case just ignore.

for mod  in module-*.git ;
    do echo $mod ;
    cd $mod;
    git diff */ivy.xml;
    cd ..; echo "";
**    read foo;**
    echo "";
done

entry.title: Blame it on the alcohol...really?
entry.content:
Glee’s “Blame it on the Alcohol” episode this week was a considerable disappointment. I speak, of course, to the influential alcohol consumption by the students of the high school. To be clear I don’t have a problem with enjoying alcoholic drinks when one is 1) at a legal drinking age and 2) responsible about it. This episode showcased that it’s ok to drink as long as you are safe regardless of the legality and it also said there’s a chance you could get a way with it and if you do, that makes it ok.

I will be the first to say that I by no means expect Glee to preach a morale message on anything morale. However, alcohol is not something to joke about or even shed light on in a silly manner. The point is that underaged teens are not allowed to drink for reason—they are not responsible enough to consume a body altering agent at whim. The consequences for the students on Glee were only but a bit of humiliation on stage with a bunch of vomiting in front of their peers…big deal.

It’s sad to me that shows that are as influential as Glee is harness their power in ways that are going to turn heads to the creators of the show for their own fame, glory, and preaching their personal agenda to the masses. Glee could do so much for its audience that would be good for everybody. It doesn’t need to have sex and alcohol to make a statement. I’ve been disappointed with a couple of other previous episodes of Glee but won’t comment on those, but this one really irked me due to the dangerous nature of alcohol in irresponsible hands.

entry.title: DIY Desktop Stand for Notebooks
entry.content:
After converting a white MacBook to our home media center, I decided the footprint was too large to lay flat with the clamshell closed on our TV stand. I came across the Twelve South BookArc and thought it would be the perfect solution to stand the MacBook on end to take up less space. However, at $50, I felt the price was a bit steep.

Thinking how I could do something similar with items I already had around the house, I thought of using a pair of metal economy bookends that I seem to have a plethora of in my home office. Note that I’m using a particular style of bookend that has a whole in the middle with the base bent down and out.

Place one bookend on top of the other’s base and slide them close together, leaving enough room to stand the MacBook up vertically between the two ends. Take the MacBook (or any notebook) and place it vertically between the two stands and slide them together to hold the notebook in place.

I used bookends that are about five inches in height which seem to hold the MacBook fairly efficiently. You could also get some black felt and glue it on the side of the bookends that touch the computer for better friction.

entry.title: Grep Git Log
entry.content:
We’ve recently switched one of our big projects at work over to Git from Perforce recently. Overall, its been good but has had quite the learning curve for all of us to shift to this new paradigm. One of the things we’ve struggled with a lot is just being able to easily see what’s changed in our commits, comparing branch to branch etc. I’m always looking for ways to slice through the information that git will report back.

I came across an interesting feature of git log yesterday. It allows you to pass a simple grep string to the git log command and only the commits that contain that string in their changeset description will be returned. This is handy for us since we label all of our descriptions with our Version One story or task ID.

The command is straightforward in its usage:

git log —grep=

This turns what could be an unwieldy output of git log commits to a simple eloquent output of a single (or shorter list) of commits:

$ git log –grep=B-03725

commit 938ec97072e6689a1065fe4aaf4ae6ae75352491

Author: Kyle Hayes < my_email >

Date: Mon Nov 15 08:42:15 2010 -0800

FE integration refs: B-03725

entry.title: Things about JavaScript I wish I knew earlier
entry.content:
Christian Hellman wrote another excellent JavaScript article over at Smashing Magazine. This time he addresses styles and techniques of coding that is widely supported, accepted, and expected by good JavaScript developers. If you’ve been programming JavaScript for awhile, you’ll notice much of the stuff is different now than it was less than a decade ago now that JavaScript has evolved and improved based on the  needs of the JavaScript community as well as the capabilities of modern-day browsers.

Personally, the ones I’ve fallen victim to most recently are shortcut notations. Having a Java background, I always wanted to create new Objects and Arrays using the “new” keyword and constructing. During the writing of Getting Started with Dojo, Peter Higgins (the technical reviewer) pounded in my head that today, objects are created like var foo = {} and arrays are created like var bar = []. Christian discusses this in the article (and a bit more in detail).

Using JSON as a data format is another one I can strongly relate to, especially with his mention of using arrays and delimited strings in the past. Today, there will not be a project that goes by where I need data brought in and I will always choose JSON if it’s available due to its native support in modern day JavaScript.

I personally am always looking for ways to make my JavaScript run faster. As developers, we so often get caught up in the moment of getting something to work and simply implement a solution in a way that just came natural and was easy, we don’t go back to see if we can make it more efficient—especially in terms of browser memory usage. There have been many times I’ve seen a simple for loop accessing data in a way that is calling another method to fetch the data, instead of caching the data once and accessing the local cache. Christian brought up another way to make your page more efficient in terms of events that I had not thought of. His example perfectly illustrates a situation in which you want to listen for the click event on a set of list items inside an unordered list. Instead of looping through each list item and adding an event handler, you can simply add an event handler to the parent of this list (the ul). From here you can determine which li was clicked. This assuming that you understand that events in the DOM roll up from the bottom when an event occurs. This means that if you click an li,if that click is not handled on the li, it will roll up to the ul and so forth.

Finally the last few points on anonymous functions with the module pattern, configuration, interacting with the back end, and browser specific code, I cannot stress enough to read and understand these the best you can. These four points that he clearly makes are utterly important in ensuring you are an efficient JavaScript developer. This will set you apart from being a good JavaScript dev, to an excellent JavaScript dev—proving you know how the language works and how to best control it and use it as it should be used.

I highly respect Christian’s articles and his advice and I recommend you head his comments where you see fit. You can read the full article on Smashing Magazine below:

http://bit.ly/amJ8sj

entry.title: Debate on Automated Acceptance Testing
entry.content:
Part of agile software development is the practice of acceptance testing to ensure the appropriate business requirements, use cases, and ensure confidence in the delivered product. This process is commonly recommended to be automated so the tests can be easily run at a given time as well as be consistent. James Shore created and encouraged the agile community to use his automated testing framework (Fit) to create these tests.

The problem is that it was meant for the business to be creating these tests, not the developers, however, it turns out that the developers were tasked with creating them instead which is a “maintenance burden”.

Shore now believes that automating the acceptance testing is not a good idea, summarized by the following two points:

1.       The real planned benefit of an automated acceptance tool, like Fit, was that the business folks (“customers”) would write executable examples themselves. History has shown that very rarely occurs. In a few cases testers do, but in the majority of cases these tests are written by the developers.

2.       These tests often become a real maintenance burden, as they are slow and brittle, and often hard to refactor. On this point, that end-to-end “integration tests” present a higher cost than they are worth, JB Rainsberger has a great series of articles explaining his rational why.

What do you think?

Full article on InfoQ: http://bit.ly/a2002q

entry.title: Easily Generate Placeholder Images in Designs and Web Pages
entry.content:
I came across a neat site called dummyimage.com that allows you to append an image size to it’s URL as so: http://dummyimage.com/300x250. However, what I didn’t like about it, is that I could not add text to the image to describe what the image is a placeholder for. I took upon myself to create my own service that does this and I plan on expanding it to do more as well.

Last night I created fpoimg.com. It works in very much the same way as dummyimage.com, only you can add text to your images. The next iteration of the site will allow you to change the colors of the background and foreground. Anyway, the way you use the site is if you want to create a basic placeholder or FPO (For Placement Only) image you simply go to http://fpoimg.com/345x480 and the image will be provided to you. You can save this image if you like, or you can refer to it directly in your code such as in an image tag: <img src="http://fpoimg.com/345x480">

The first number is your width in pixels, the second is your height in pixels. Additionally, if you want to add some text to the image to describe it as a placeholder, you simply append that to the URL as so: http://fpoimg.com/345x480/Advertisement

This will create the following image:

It’s really that basic! Here are some more examples:

I of course do plan on tweaking this service as needed such as caching the images and providing the ability to change their colors. If the service becomes more popular, I have a feeling I’ll need to invoke some kind of limit as well so as not to crash the server.
